Award.AbstractNarration:
Most directions of the research supported by this grant revolve around geometry of group actions on various spaces and geometric structures on manifolds, as well as geometry of buildings. In more details, research conducted by M. Kapovich concerns: (1) Geometry of buildings with applications to representation theory. Kapovich intends to continue his study of the geometry of the moduli spaces of polygonal linkages in symmetric spaces and buildings in relation to the algebraic groups. Part of this study is establishing tropical structures on Euclidean buildings. (2) Kleinian groups in higher dimensions: Kapovich will study finiteness properties of higher-dimensional Kleinian groups. (3) Fundamental groups of complex-projective varieties: Kapovich will study fundamental groups of irreducible complex-projective varieties whose singularities are normal crossings. (4) Kapovich will study embeddings of Right-angled Artin Groups in the group of diﬀeomorphisms of the circle. (5) Semihyperbolicity of Teichmuller space: Kapovich will study coarse nonpositive curvature properties of Teichmuller space. (6) Kapovich will study classification of fundamental groups of closed 4-dimensional manifolds M with trivial 2nd homotopy group.

The goal of this research is to understand better interaction between geometry and groups. Groups appear naturally as symmetries of natural geometric objects. Simple examples of such symmetries come from wall-paper tilings (where geometry is Euclidean) or tilings appearing is some of the Escher pictures (hyperbolic geometry). Furthermore, groups appear as symmetries of geometric objects of physical nature, from elementary particles to the entire universe (treated as a geometric object). Algebra (group theory) allows one to encode the underlying symmetries, and, conversely, geometry allows one to approach successfully purely algebraic problems. One of the examples of such interaction of seemingly different mathematical fields is project (3), which aims to apply groups of symmetries of 3-dimensional hyperbolic space to complex-algebraic geometry (the latter deals with geometry of solution spaces of systems of polynomial equations with complex variables).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project dealt with geometry of discrete groups, such as symmetry groups of geometric objects. In process, new connections between different branches of geometry and group theory were established. Among major results that PI obtained during the support period are: 

1. A variety of equivalent characterizations of Anosov representations of hyperbolic groups and proofs of proper discontinuity and cocompactness results.

2. A higher rank analogue of the classical Morse Lemma which describes shapes of certain classes of curves.

3. Proof of decidability (and undecidability) of several problems related to discrete subgroups of connected Lie groups.

4. Isomorphism between maximal Satake compactifications of symmetric spaces and compactifications via suitable horoboundaries of Finsler metrics. 

5. In 1960s Stan Ulam has posed the following general question: "When is it true that the solution of an equation differing slightly from a given one, must of necessity be close to the solution of the given equation?" As one specific example, Ulam considered  "quasihomomorphisms of groups". In the work of Kapovich, a structure theorem for quasihomomorphisms into finitely generated noncommutative groups: All quasihomomorphisms come from several functorial constructions (up to passage to finite index subgroups and bounded perturbation). This result, to some extent, answers a problem raised by Stan Ulam in the context of group homomorphisms. On the other hand, with a modification of the notion of quasihomomorphisms, a new construction mimicking Brooks' construction.

6. An answer to a problem raised by Carlos Simpson on fundamental groups of irreducible projective varieties with normal crossing singularities.

7. A universality theorem for character schemes of SL(2)-­representations of 3­manifold groups. In particular, any singularity over Z can be realized and the character scheme can be nonreduced.
